    • Field Detail

      • NONE

        public static final StandardValue NONE

      • UNDEFINED

        public static final StandardValue UNDEFINED

      • bytesSegment

        protected BytesSegment bytesSegment
        This is only ever a reference to either localBytes or to an external byte array. The advantage of localBytes is not that the value is immutable, rather that it can only be changed through methods on this object. If someone stores the raw bytes somewhere, then this value changes, the raw bytes will change. However, at least the data is owned by this object and nobody else.

        protected String stringValue

        public void convert(int type,
                    IValue other)
             throws ConversionException
        Description copied from interface: IValue
        Copies value from another IValue object into this one, converting the value to the given type.

        Note that if type == other.getNativeType, this is equivalent to IValue.copyFrom(IValue).

        Specified by:

        Parameters:
        type - Type to be converted to - see IValue.TYPE_xxx constants.
        other - IValue whose value is to be converted.
        Throws:
        ConversionException - if value cannot be converted.

        public boolean equals(Object obj)
        Description copied from interface: IValue
        True if two values are equal without any type conversion.

        For example a String value "2" would not be considered as equal to an int value of 2, because IValue.getNativeType() returns different types.

        Specified by:

        Overrides:
        equals in class Object
        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • getValueAsAsciiBytes

        public BytesSegment getValueAsAsciiBytes()
                                  throws ConversionException
        Description copied from interface: IValue
        Returns the bytes making up the ASCII string.

        May return null if no value is defined.

        Code using this method should not assume that the BytesSegment returned is a pristine one, that is, if you need to access the underlying byte array you should not reference the BytesSegment.bytes variable directly but use the BytesSegment.copyBytes() method instead.

        Specified by:
        getValueAsAsciiBytes in interface IValue
        Returns:
        String bytes - may be null.
        Throws:
        ConversionException - If value cannot be converted.

      • accessInternalBytesSegment

        public BytesSegment accessInternalBytesSegment()
        Description copied from interface: IValue
        Provides access to the value's internal byte array.

        Access is provided through the value's internal BytesSegment modified to point to the internal byte array.

        If no BytesSegment exists, an empty one is created.

        This is a low level method which should not normally be used. It can be useful when an IValue object is being reused and you want to reuse the internal byte array from a previous value.

        Note that this call will destroy the existing value if that value is a reference to external bytes because the underlying BytesSegment is changed to point to the value's own internal byte array.

        Typical use of this method would be: 

           BytesSegment bs = v.accessInternalBytesSegment();
   //Suppose we want to copy in n bytes
   bs.grow(n, false);
 
   ...Copy n bytes into bs.bytes starting from index 0.
 
   bs.start = 0;
   bs.length = n;
   //Now use one of the standard set methods which takes a BytesSegment
   //to complete setting the value. For example...
   v.setValueAsAsciiBytes( bs, false );
   //Note that the set method was called with copy false.
   //This is because the bytes have already been copied where they
   //need to be.
        Specified by:
        accessInternalBytesSegment in interface IValue
        Returns:
        The underlying BytesSegment. Never returns null, but the returned BytesSegment may be empty - that is the bytes attribute of the BytesSegment may be null.

      • getNativeType

        public int getNativeType()
        Description copied from interface: IValue
        Returns the type that this value was defined with.

        Type constants are declared in IValue.TYPE_xxx.

        For example if the value was set as as int, int is its native type even though you could retrieve a String representation of that int.

        Specified by:
        getNativeType in interface IValue
        Returns:
        int specifying the native type of this value or -1 indicating undefined.

      • getTypeName

        public static String getTypeName(int type)
        Returns the name corresponding to the given type - as defined by the TYPE constants in IValue eg IValue.TYPE_SignedInt32.

        If the type value is unknown, the returned name is just a String representation of the value.

        Parameters:
        type - Type as defined by the IValue TYPE constants
        Returns:
        String name of given type

      • isNone

        public boolean isNone()
        Description copied from interface: IValue
        The value is empty.

        Note that this is different from undefined. We have a defined value - which is empty. Undefined means that we do not know the value at all.

        Specified by:
        isNone in interface IValue
        Returns:
        True if the value is empty.

      • isUndefined

        public boolean isUndefined()
        Description copied from interface: IValue
        The value is undefined, i.e IValue.TYPE_Unknown. Note that the type could be defined (as returned by getNativeType), but the value is undefined.

        Undefined means that a value is not currently used. This allows implementations of ITagValues to pool discarded objects for reuse when they are no longer needed, rather than deleting and creating new values/tag values.

        Specified by:
        isUndefined in interface IValue
        Returns:
        True if the value is undefined.

        setValueAsAsciiBytes in interface IValue
        Parameters:

        start - Start of bytes making up string
        length - Number of bytes in string
        copy - If true a copy should be made of the bytes passed in (slower, but safer). If false a reference to the passed in byte[] will be kept instead.

      • setValue

        public void setValue(byte[] bytes,
                     int start,
                     int length,
                     boolean copy)
        Description copied from interface: IValue
        Set bytes in byte vector value.

        Bytes in vector are valueBytes[ valueStart ] .. valueBytes[ valueStart + valueLength -1 ].

        Specified by:
        setValue in interface IValue
        Parameters:
        bytes - Array containing valueBytes.
        start - Bytes in vector valueStart at this index of array.
        length - Number of bytes in vector.
        copy - If true a copy should be made of the bytes passed in (slower, but safer). If false a reference to the passed in byte[] will be kept instead.

      • setValue

        public void setValue(byte[] bytes,
                     int start,
                     int length,
                     boolean copy,
                     String charsetName)
        Description copied from interface: IValue
        Set bytes in byte vector value. The bytes are assumed to be a String encoded using the specified character set.

        Bytes in vector are valueBytes[ valueStart ] .. valueBytes[ valueStart + valueLength -1 ].

        Specified by:
        setValue in interface IValue
        Parameters:
        bytes - Array containing valueBytes.
        start - Bytes in vector valueStart at this index of array.
        length - Number of bytes in vector.
        copy - If true a copy should be made of the bytes passed in (slower, but safer). If false a reference to the passed in byte[] will be kept instead.
        charsetName - The character set name (encoding) for this field. Will be used in IValue.getValueAsString().

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object

      • setValue

        public void setValue(int type,
                     String value)
              throws ConversionException
        Sets a value of the given type computed by parsing the given String value.

        This encapsulates the rules as described in the "Type Conversion" section of the FAST 1.1 specification.

        If value is null, equivalent to setNone(int) passing in type.

        Parameters:
        type - Type of target value.
        value - String from which target value is derived.
        Throws:
        ConversionException - if the value cannot be converted to the given type.

      • setValue

        public void setValue(int type,
                     long value)
              throws ConversionException
        Sets a value of the given type computed by converting the given long value.

        This encapsulates the rules as described in the "Type Conversion" section of the FAST 1.1 specification.

        Parameters:
        type - Type of target value.
        value - long from which target value is derived.
        Throws:
        ConversionException - if the value cannot be converted to the given type.

      • setValue

        public void setValue(int type,
                     Decimal value)
              throws ConversionException
        Sets a value of the given type computed by converting the given decimal value.

        This encapsulates the rules as described in the "Type Conversion" section of the FAST 1.1 specification.

        Parameters:
        type - Type of target value.
        value - decimal from which target value is derived.
        Throws:
        ConversionException - if the value cannot be converted to the given type.

      • getCharsetName

        public String getCharsetName()
        Description copied from interface: IValue
        Return the character set associated with this encoded field if set via IValue.setValue(byte[], int, int, boolean, String)
        Specified by:
        getCharsetName in interface IValue
        Returns:
        The character set name (encoding) for this field, or null if this is a normal (i.e. non-encoded) field.
